Dear DANA KOZIARA:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
September 20, 2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Jennifer Pastorick, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4111 Job description.
(1) An institution shall provide a job description for each
staff position that identifies rules, required
qualifications, and lines of authority.
Three of seven new employee files reviewed lacked the employees job
description.
2

CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records for
each employee and shall include documentation of all
of the following information prior to employment or at
the time specified in this rule:
(c) Verification of high school diploma or GED when
specified by rule.
Two of seven new employee files reviewed lacked verification of education.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records for
each employee and shall include documentation of all
of the following information prior to employment or at
the time specified in this rule:
(d) Work history.
One of seven new employee files reviewed lacked work history.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records for
each employee and shall include documentation of all
of the following information prior to employment or at
the time specified in this rule:
(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior
to employment from persons unrelated to the employee
and which are less than 12 months old.
Four of seven new employee files reviewed lacked three dated references.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records for
each employee and shall include documentation of all
of the following information prior to employment or at
the time specified in this rule:
(i) Documentation from the Michigan department of
human services, the equivalent state or Canadian
provincial agency, or equivalent agency in the country
where the person usually resides, that the person has
not been determined to be a perpetrator of child abuse
3

or child neglect. The documentation shall be completed
not more than 30 days prior to the start of employment
and every 12 months thereafter.
Two of seven new employee files reviewed did not have central registry clearance
prior to the employee being hired.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records for
each employee and shall include documentation of all
of the following information prior to employment or at
the time specified in this rule:
(j) A written evaluation of the employee’s
performance within 30 days of the completion of the
probationary period or within 180 days, whichever is
less, and a written evaluation of the employee’s
performance annually thereafter
One of three employee files who had been employeed over a year did not have
an annual performance evaluation.
CCI Rule 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and
volunteers.
(1) The licensee shall document, prior to employment,
that each employee and volunteer who has contact
with residents 4 or more hours per week for more than
2 consecutive weeks is free from communicable
tuberculosis. Freedom from communicable tuberculosis
shall be verified within the 1-year period before
employment and shall be verified every 1 year after the
last verification or prior to the expiration of the current
verification.
One of seven new employee files reviewed did not have documentation of a
tuberculosis screening.
CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio.
(4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of
the direct supervision of staff, staff shall perform
variable interval, eye-on checks of residents. The time
between the variable interval checks shall not exceed
fifteen minutes.
4

In reviewing youth check logs, it was found varying interval checks are not being
completed as checks were being completed every fifteen minutes and some
checks exceeded the fifteen minutes.
CCI Rule 400.4128 Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training.
(1) The licensee shall provide an orientation program
for new employees. Job shadowing shall not be the
only form of orientation. The orientation shall include
the following:
(a) The institution’s purpose, policies, and
procedures, including discipline, crisis intervention
techniques, and emergency and safety procedures
Two of seven new employee files reviewed lacked orientation training to Cedar
Creek as the staff were initially hired for another facility and were then reassigned
to Cedar Creek.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Updating the facilities program statement to reflect the youth that are accepted
into the program as well as the avenues youth are referred through.
• Central Registry clearance must be received prior to the facility making a hiring
decision.
• Discharge planning needs to be addressed in the initial treatment plan and
discussed the importance of documenting plans for next placement specifically for
a current youth who will need to move in the near future.
• Documenting parent(s) and referral source input in service plans and if input was
not sought, the reasons why.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Discussed fire extinguishers as the facility currently has moved the fire
extinguishers into the staff office due to a safety concern with a youth. Reviewed
CCI Rule 400.4532.
• Discussed continued efforts and continued documentation of efforts being made
to enroll a youth in school due to difficulties the facility is having with enrolling the
youth due to the youth being denied from two school districts.
5

• Discussed consistency in documentation of all social work contacts made during
the service plan period as well as documentation of therapy sessions.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has not been required to submit any corrective action plans during this
period under review.
Financial Overview
Teaching Family Homes annual third-party audit report for fiscal year ending
September 30, 2022, was reviewed by the Bureau of Audit. The audit report
included financial concerns however the concerns are improving. Net assets
indicate the extent to which revenues exceed expensed and is an indicator of the
financial health of an organization. The agency has a deficit in total net assets in
the negative, however this has improved from the previous year audit. The facility
has a working capital in the negative, which indicates an agency's inability to pay
off its short-term liability if they came due immediately, however this too has
improved from the previous year audit. The facilities financial condition will
continue to be monitored in subsequent audits, however there is improvement in
this fiscal year's financial audit.
Chief Administrator Assessment
Cedar Creek began accepting youth into the facility in mid-August 2023 and prior to
accepting youth, the facility had not been utilized in a couple of years. There have
been no areas of non-compliance since accepting youth back into the facility. The
current plan is to remain with three youth at the facility until the current youth adjust
to the program. Once the facility feels comfortable with the current youth, the
facility plans to accept more youth into the program.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Three employees were interviewed during the onsite visit. Staff report feeling safe
and supported in the facility. Staff reported no concerns or needs at this time. Staff
report overall it has been going well since beginning to accept youth back into the
facility.
Interviews with youth were conducted. Youth report feeling safe, respected, and
treated with dignity at the facility. Youth report their needs being met. Youth are
receiving medications as prescribed, therapy services regularly, clean clothing and
bedding, and appropriate meals.
Description of Agency Walk Through
6

A walk through of the facility was completed during the onsite visit. The facility was
clean, and no safety concerns were noted. Medications and cleaning chemicals are
stored appropriately. All bedrooms had appropriate bedding. The kitchen was clean
with the menu posted on the refrigerator. The facility had emergency plans posted
and the intent to check criminal history posted on the outside of the staff office
door.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
